JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in Gdańsk . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
DATE and CARDINAL DATE the applicant served CARDINAL terms of imprisonment imposed on him in separate sets of criminal proceedings .

On DATE the ORG charged the applicant with CARDINAL counts of unlawful possession of firearms , unlawful possession of explosives and theft of a driving licence . On DATE the ORG ordered his detention pending trial in view of the reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed the offences with which he had been charged . It further held that the applicant might obstruct the proceedings and had regard to the severity of the penalty likely to be imposed . The court found that imposition of detention pending trial at the time when the applicant was serving a prison term would enable the prosecution to effectively control his contact with the outside world .

On DATE the ORG dismissed an appeal by the applicant against the detention order . It held that keeping him in custody was justified by the severity of the likely penalty and the risk that he might tamper with evidence , given the substantial number of suspects in the case .

The applicant ’s appeal against the detention order , likewise his further appeals against decisions extending his detention and all his subsequent , numerous applications for release and appeals against refusals to release him , were unsuccessful . In his applications and appeals , he argued in particular that his detention had been automatically extended by the courts .
In the course of the investigation , the applicant ’s detention was extended on CARDINAL occasions , namely , on DATE and DATE .

On an unknown date in DATE the ORG refused to allow the applicant a visit from his common - law wife . The applicant filed a complaint . On DATE ORG refused to institute criminal proceedings in respect of the applicant ’s complaint .

On DATE ORG lodged a bill of indictment with ORG . The applicant was charged with CARDINAL counts of unlawful possession of firearms , unlawful possession of explosives and theft of a driving licence . The bill of indictment comprised CARDINAL charges brought against CARDINAL defendants . Other defendants were charged with numerous counts of robbery and armed robbery committed in an organised criminal group . However , the applicant was not charged with acting in such a group .

On DATE the ORG extended the applicant ’s detention until DATE , finding that it was necessary in order to prevent him DATE and his other CARDINAL detained co - defendants – from evading justice or tampering with evidence .

On DATE the ORG again extended the detention of the applicant and that of CARDINAL of his co - defendants , considering that the grounds originally given for remanding him in custody were still valid .
The trial began on DATE . However , as of DATE the prosecution had still not completed the reading - out of the bill of indictment .

During the court proceedings the authorities extended the applicant ’s detention on DATE and DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE , and DATE . The courts repeated the grounds previously given for the applicant ’s continued detention . In particular , they referred to the complexity of the case , the volume of evidence and the severity of the likely penalty .
DATE and DATE the applicant was serving a prison sentence imposed in another set of criminal proceedings against him .

On DATE the trial court ordered the applicant ’s release . It noted the charges against the applicant and the fact that the period of his detention had exceeded DATE . The court held that the detention should be lifted .

By DATE the trial court had held CARDINAL hearings and heard evidence from CARDINAL witnesses . However , all the hearings listed after DATE had to be cancelled due to the long - term illness of CARDINAL of the trial court judges . Subsequently , a new panel of judges had to be assigned to the case and the trial had to be restarted .

On DATE ORG considered that the case concerning the charges against the applicant and some of the charges against CARDINAL of his co - accused should be examined separately . The case was subsequently examined by ORG .
On DATE ORG transferred the applicant ’s case to ORG , which had meanwhile become competent to try the case .
It appears that the proceedings against the applicant are pending .

The relevant domestic law and practice concerning the imposition of detention during the judicial proceedings ( aresztowanie tymczasowe ) , the grounds for its extension , release from detention and rules governing other “ preventive measures ” ( środki zapobiegawcze ) are stated in the ORG ’s judgments in the cases of ORG v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , CARDINAL DATE and PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § DATE , CARDINAL DATE .
